metadata.title: Joubert Syndrome  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: joubert syndrome and related disorders  occupational therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Multiple parts of the body can be affected, including the central nervous system (CNS), the eyes, the musculoskeletal system, the liver, and the kidneys
description: Joubert syndrome (JS) is a rare congenital neurological disorder characterized by abnormalities of the cerebellum.(1) JS is one of a group of genetic conditions and syndromes that share a similar cerebellar malformation, and these are referred to as JS and related disorders (JSRDs).(1) The collection of cerebellar abnormalities associated with JSRDs is referred to as the molar tooth sign (MTS) when it is seen on an MRI scan and is the main diagnostic criterion for JS/JSRD.(1,2) Individuals with JS or a related disorder have some of the same characteristics; however, there is a spectrum of symptoms and a range of abilities in affected individuals

The MTS is characterized by hypoplasia (underdevelopment) or agenesis (absence) of the cerebellar vermis, abnormally deep and long interpeduncular fossa at the isthmus and upper pons, a sagittal vermian cleft, and horizontalized, thickened, and elongated cerebellar peduncles. reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified. In the United States, patients may qualify for individual state-funded  therapy programs (birth-21)  through contracted therapy vendors and/or the school system. The qualifications are state specific
presentation signs and symptoms: The clinical presentation of JS/JSRDs is heterogeneous and can include neurological signs/symptoms as well as involvement of the musculoskeletal and organ systems, including the eyes, kidneys, and liver(1)

In a genetic sequencing study of 440 patients in the United States affected by JS, retinal disease was present in 30% of individuals, renal disease in 25%, coloboma (i.e., a hole in one of structures of the eye) in 17%, polydactyly (i.e., having an extra finger or toe) in 15%, liver fibrosis in 14%, and encephalocele in 8%(23)

Common signs and symptoms of JS/JSRD include: –Neurological issues -Hypotonia(1,4) -Hypotonia is seen in the neonatal or infancy period in almost all patients with JS/JSRD(1) -Infants with JS/JSRD are likely to have froglike posturing in a supine position, similar to a premature infant(4) -Drooling can result from hypotonia of the oral musculature -Ataxia(1,4) –Associated with broad-based  gait during the first few years of independent walking(1) –CNS abnormalities in addition to MTS can include: -Hydrocephalous(1) -Cystic enlargement of the posterior fossa(1) -Deformities of the corpus callosum(1) -Cysts in the white matter of the brain(1) -Hypothalamic hamartoma (benign growth of the hypothalamus)(1) –Absence of the pituitary gland(1) –Abnormal migration defects (occurs during embryonic development of the brain; marked by abnormally located neurons in the brain; in individuals with JS, the most common type is periventricular nodular heterotopias)(1) -Individuals with JS/JSRD who have these migration defects have an increased risk of epilepsy(1) –Head titubation(21) -Presents as horizontal head tremor with high frequency and small amplitude, and gradually decreases over time with spontaneous resolution -United States researchers conducted a retrospective study and concluded that head titubation was first recognized in the first 2 months of age and decreased in severity until spontaneous resolution. In 12/13 children diagnosed with JS/JSRD, the head titubation was horizontal, with high frequency (~3Hz), small amplitude (5-10°),  never present during sleep, and did not interfere with the neurodevelopment during infancy. In the majority of children, emotion, anxiety, and tiredness were worsening factors for head titubation(22) –Head thrusts(21) -Head thrusts are not rhythmical and are not exacerbated by fatigue, emotion, or stress -Typically present around 6 months of age, after a child has acquired head and neck control –Sensory processing deficits

Developmental issues –Developmental delay(1) -Motor skills are typically delayed in all individuals with JS/JSRD, but the degree of severity varies from mild to severe(1) -For additional information on assessment and treatment of children with developmental delays, see  Clinical Review… Developmental Disabilities in Children: Occupational Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709155 –Intellectual and cognitive impairments(1) -The authors of a cohort study of 54 Italian patients, aged 10 months to 29 years of age, found variable cognitive function (IQ range 32-129),  emotional and behavioral issues, decreased motor function, but generally preserved communication skills within the group(25)  –Delayed attainment of speech/language milestones(1) –Apraxia of speech(5)

Respiratory problems –Abnormal or irregular neonatal respiratory patterns(1) -Can present as episodes of hyperpnea or as alternating episodes of apnea and hyperpnea(1,4) -Individuals with prolonged episodes of apnea might require mechanical ventilation(1) -Is exacerbated by emotional stress but improves with age(1)

Ophthalmological issues –The retina is frequently affected by JS/JSRD, typically in the form of retinal dysplasia due to progressive degeneration of photoreceptor cells(1,6) -Individuals with JS/JSRD who have retinal involvement can have visual impairments that range from congenital retinal blindness (Leber congenital amaurosis [LCA]) to relatively intact vision(1,3) –Atypical ocular movements(1,3,6) -Oculomotor apraxia (OMA) is a frequent finding in individuals with JS/JSRD(1) -There is a strong correlation between oculomotor impairment and the intensity of head titubation(21) –Less frequently occurring ophthalmological issues -Coloboma(1,4) -In individuals with JS/JSRD, colobomas typically affect the posterior portion of the eye(1) -Nystagmus(1,3,4) -Strabismus(1) -Ptosis(1) –For additional information on assessment and treatment of patients with visual impairments, see Clinical Review…Visual Dysfunction: Occupational Therapy; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708963

Renal issues –Renal involvement occurs in 2-20%  of JS cases and can even lead to renal failure in early childhood(24) –Renal problems are strongly associated with retinal dystrophy in individuals with JS/JSRD(7) –Renal disease/renal insufficiency occurs in 25% of individuals with JS/JSRD, mostly in the form of nephronophthisis (NPH)(1,3) -NPH in the juvenile form is marked by chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis that progresses to terminal renal failure sometime in the first and second decades of life; infantile NPH manifests within the first few years of life and has a much more rapid disease course and poorer prognosis(1) –Cystic dysplastic kidney (CDK)(1) -Marked by abnormal kidney development with oversized kidneys and the presence of kidney cysts(1)

Liver disease –Occurs in a minority of individuals with JS/JSRD(1) –Problems with the liver in individuals with JS/JSRD usually occur as a result of congenital hepatic fibrosis(1) -COACH syndrome (cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, oligophrenia [developmental or intellectual disability], ataxia, colobomas, hepatic fibrosis) is a subtype of JS/JSRD(3,8)

Skeletal issues –Polydactyly (abnormal number of digits; can affect hands or feet)(1,3) -Can co-occur  with oral/facial defects; referred to as Varadi-Papp  syndrome or orofaciodigital type VI(1) -With Varadi-Papp  syndrome, oral/facial abnormalities may include a highly arched or cleft palate, tongue clefts, tongue nodules, cleft lip, multiple lingual/labial frenula, and broad nasal tip(1) –Mild to severe scoliosis(1,3)

Facial features –Facial features of individuals with JS/JSRD are often abnormal in appearance, but vary in individuals affected by the syndrome(3) –Possible abnormal facial features include far-set  eyes, small pinnae, large/broad forehead, arched eyebrows, and wide mouth Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: The occupational therapist (OT) must be aware of cultural considerations when assessing an individual with JS/JSRD as well as when developing treatment goals. Needs of the patient should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting

Family members/caregivers should be involved in both the assessment and treatment of pediatric patients as they have a unique perspective and can provide information on the child that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures

risk factors: Family history of JS/JSRD or having parents who are both carriers of a genetic mutation associated with JS/JSRD

overall contraindications precautions: For children with JS/JSRD, development of an individualized family service plan (IFSP) or individual education plan (IEP) in collaboration with the parents/guardians and early intervention/school personnel is essential to address global developmental delays and swallowing impairments in the home and school environment
For individuals with JS/JSRD who have seizures, observe seizure precautions to reduce the risk of injury if a seizure were to occur
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was the diagnosis of JS/JSRD made and by whom?  -JS/JSRD is included in the differential diagnosis of infants who present with hypotonia, abnormal ocular movements, and developmental delay. Diagnosis of JS/JSRD is confirmed by an MRI of the brain that shows the presence of the MTS(1,3,4)

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical and surgical management of JS/JSRD to date
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Patients with JS/JSRD are highly sensitive to respiratory depressants, and such medications should be administered with extreme caution(20)
diagnostic tests completed: MTS and vermian hypoplasia are the hallmark signs of JS/JSRD on MRI(1)
Ophthalmological evaluation, including electroretinogram, if possible, to determine if there is involvement of the retina(1,3,7)
Ophthalmological evaluations should be repeated on a yearly basis to monitor for changes in vision(3)
Assessments of the kidneys and liver
Abdominal ultrasound of the kidneys and liver to examine structural abnormalities(1)
Genetic testing to evaluate which specific genetic mutation(s) have caused JS/JSRD(7)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Does the patient have hearing or vision difficulties? -Does the patient have speech and language deficits that increase frustration or exacerbate behavioral problems? -Is the patient overly sensitive to sensory stimulation (visual, auditory, or tactile)?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (see Presentation/signs & symptoms , above)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain  is present now and how much ) -For pediatric patients, use Oucher or FLACC scale
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Sleep disturbances in individuals with JS/JSRD can be caused by respiratory complications, abnormal breathing patterns, or obstructive or central sleep apnea(3,12)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient require mechanical ventilation? Psychosocial status -Children with JS/JSRD can become frustrated if they are unable to express themselves adequately to communication partners; parents of these children have reported severe temper tantrums(7) -Developmental questionnaires can provide information on behavioral issuesa 300-item  parent questionnaire that provides information on the development, disease-related  symptoms, and behavior problems of children ages 15 months to 6 years(13)  -There is increased caregiver burden when caring for a child with JS/JSRD.(13) Parents of children with JS/JSRD may have difficulty coping with the diagnosis and can experience grief and/or depression(4,13) -Formal measures of caregiver coping mechanisms, burden, and depression that could be administered during a -Beck Depression Inventory(13) -Family Assessment Device(13) -Caregiver Strain Index(13) -Ways of Coping Checklist—Revised(13) -Document symptoms of psychosocial disturbance or behavioral problems in the patient as well as within the patient’s family (e.g., symptoms of depression, feelings of guilt or isolation, signs of abuse or neglect) and refer family to a social worker or psychologist if necessary(13)Document hearing ability, including any hearing loss and/or use of hearing aids or other assistive hearing device -Sensorineural hearing loss is not a typical feature of JS/JSRD; however, middle ear infections should be treated promptly to minimize conductive hearing loss(14) -In a study of 22 patients with JS conducted in the Netherlands, researchers found that middle ear infections resulting in conductive hearing loss occurred in 6 of these patients (27%), a percentage that is not significantly higher than the general population(14) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document history of any other congenital, feeding, or developmental abnormalities. Document if any prior occupational therapy evaluation has been completed; if it has, review past reports
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask parent/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Does the patient currently receive intervention services? If so, are they home, school, hospital, or clinic based? Does the patient attend daycare/preschool/school? -Does the patient live at home? If the patient is an adult, does he or she have a job? -Is the patient involved in the community? Is the patient involved in leisure activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Document if and what type of adaptive equipment the patient is using, such as wheelchairs, hearing aids, or glasses -Determine the effect of the patient’s functional deficits on participation in school, social, and occupational activities
social and occupational history.living environment: Obtain information on the patient’s family as well as a description of his or her living environment. Document languages spoken in the home or at school. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  A combination of standardized assessment measures, caregiver questionnaires, and play-based observation should be used to evaluate a patient with JS/JSRD
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s and caregiver’s needs for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices –Adaptive feeding equipment -Adaptive utensils -Adaptive plates/bowls -Adaptive cups and/or bottles/nipples –Mobility aids -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) -Cane -Crutches -Walker -Wheelchair –Toileting equipment -Grab bars next to the toilet -Bedside commode -Raised toilet seat -Elevated foot rest at the toilet –ADL/IADL aides such as reachers, long-handled  equipment, shoe horn,dressing sticks, sock aids, elastic shoe laces, modified eating utensils, adaptive toys or play equipment, adaptive writing utensils, text-to-speech  software
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance reactions in sitting and standing positions with eyes open and closed –Individuals with JS/JSRD are likely to have balance impairment/ataxia due to involvement of the cerebellum(1,4) –Use Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS). Refer patient to physical therapy for a formal assessment if patient presents with balance impairments –Document the presence of head titubation, head thrust, or ataxia
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pedal pulses; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesAssess bed mobility and transfers (including toilet and tub transfers) and determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity safely –Test static and dynamic functional activities –Timed Up & Go (TUG) test(16) – a measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility –Use WeeFIM or FIM(17)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Briefly assess gait –Individuals with JS/JSRD typically have a broad-based  gait during the first few years of independent walking(1) –Note presence of ataxia, head titubation, or head thrust –Refer to physical therapy for full gait assessment and intervention if appropriateAssess bilateral upper and lower extremity joint mobility and note any hypo or hypermobility. Use the Beighton Scale for HypermobilityAssess upper extremity grasp and release as well as coordination; assess patient’s trunk and upper/lower extremities for tonal abnormalities and isolated motor control –Most individuals with JS/JSRD present with hypotonia(1,4) -Hypotonia is seen in the neonatal or infancy period in almost all patients with JS/JSRD(1) -Infants with JS/JSRD are likely to have froglike posturing in a supine position, similar to a premature infant(4)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity muscle strength with manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers;MMT is not appropriate if the patient presents with joint contractures –For children who are unable to follow MMT commands or younger children, assess muscle strength through function (e.g., raising arms against gravity or in an antigravity position). Note any asymmetry or abnormality –Use handheld dynamometer and pinch gauge to evaluate grip and pinch strengthAssess with standardized neuromotor development tests, such as –Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)
observation inspection palpation includi: The retina is frequently affected by JS/JSRD, typically in the form of retinal dystrophy from progressive degeneration of photoreceptor cells(1,6) -Individuals with JS/JSRD who have retinal involvement can have vision problems that range from congenital retinal blindness (LCA) to relatively intact vision(1,3)
OMA is a frequent finding in individuals with JS/JSRD(1)
For additional information on assessment and treatment of patients with visual impairments, see Clinical Review…Visual Dysfunction: Occupational Therapy , referenced above
relevant tests and measures.posture: Note postural deficits; patients with JS/JSRD are at increased risk for scoliosis due to hypotonia(1,3) –Assess sitting, standing, and walking posture –Assess the patient’s ability to utilize support (i.e., assistive device or arm support) to improve both standing and walking posture; note posture with/without adaptive equipment –Document static/dynamic posture in both sitting/standing throughout a variety of tasks
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess functional ROM of the upper and lower extremities as well as the spineAssess ADLs –Individuals with JS/JSRD will likely require caregiver assistance with ADLs(13) –There is significant range of abilities among individuals with JS/JSRD(7) -Individuals with mild physical and cognitive abilities are likely to achieve functional independence with toileting and self-feeding; however, if physical and cognitive disabilities are severe, the patient may never be able to complete ADL tasks(7) –FIM testing is appropriate for assessment of ADLs(17) -For children with JS, the WeeFIM is appropriate for assessment of ADLs(18) -The WeeFIM assesses basic daily living and functional skills in children from birth to 7 years of age(18)self-care,  sphincter control, transfers, locomotion, communication, and social cognition(18)Assess patient’s ability to dress and/or cooperate with dressing activities when assisted by parent/caregiverAssess grooming skills -What type of assistance does the patient require for grooming, shaving, brushing the teeth, etc.?Assess the patient’s ability to feed himself or herself; is assistance or adaptive feeding equipment required? -Refer to reports of speech-language  pathologist (SLP) regarding swallowing function and aspiration riskDocument level of assistance needed; does the patient currently use adaptive toileting equipment?
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess light touch, pinprick, position sensation (proprioception and kinesthesia), vibration, and temperature –Primary cilia are important for perception of sensory input, and damage to these cilia leads to sensory processing deficits in individuals with JS/JSRD(9) –For additional information on assessment and treatment of sensory processing disorders, see Clinical Review…SensoryPediatrics ; CINAHL Topic ID Number
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales (V ABS) -Formal assessment of adaptive behavior assessing domains of communication, daily living, socialization, and motor skills -Norms for children aged 0 to 18 years, 11 months
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document if the patient is alert and oriented x 4. Does the patient have difficulty performing simple or complex multistep commands? Does the patient have difficulty focusing and attending to task?  –Document the results of any cognitive or neuropsychological testing that has been previously completed. Although individuals with JS/JSRD typically have some degree of intellectual disability, ranging from mild to severe,(1,3,7) case studies have documented individuals with JS/JSRD with cognitive functioning in the average range(15,25) –Learning disabilities are common among individuals with JS/JSRD; however, this is not always a feature of the syndrome(7) –Accurate assessment of intelligence and developmental level can be difficult in individuals with JS/JSRD due to the severity of motor and speech impairments(3,7)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

To ensure relevance and appropriateness of treatment programs, decisions about goals and course of therapy should be made in collaboration with the patient, caregivers, and other healthcare professionals. It is highly recommended that family members be involved in the rehabilitation process as much as possible
Clinician should carefully consider the patient’s stamina and medical status before beginning therapy
Cultural background, language preference, and patient interests must be considered when planning treatment goals and activities
Precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, behavioral, and/or motor symptoms

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: An OT will determine if an individual with JS/JSRD who has functional deficits and/or developmental delays as a result of the physical and cognitive impairments associated with the syndrome is an appropriate candidate for occupational therapy following the completion of a comprehensive evaluation
assessment plan of care.rule out: Prior to diagnosing the patient with JS/JSRD, the patient’s medical team will rule out other possible disorders/ syndromes, including: Senior-Loken  syndrome(1) Bardet-Biedl  syndrome(1) CHARGE syndrome(7) Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTNB)(4) Dandy-Walker  malformation(4) Arima syndrome(4) Cerebellar dysplasia(4) Congenital ataxia(4) Oligophrenia(4) Juvenile nephronophthisis(4) Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia(4) Congenital muscular dystrophy(4)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physical therapist (PT) for evaluation and treatment of developmental delays, balance, and gait disturbance(1) SLP for evaluation and treatment of speech/language and/or feeding/swallowing skills(1)  Urologist and/or nephrologist for involvement of the kidneys(1) Hepatologist and/or gastroenterologist for involvement of the liver(1) Ophthalmologist for involvement of the retina, OMA, and other eye-related  problems(1,6) Neurologist for management of neurological deficits and complications Neuropsychologist for comprehensive cognitive testing Social worker/mental health professional for psychosocial issues or for family support

maintenance or prevention: There is no known means of preventing JS/JSRDs The parents of a child with JS/JSRD might benefit from genetic counseling to determine their risk of having another child with JS/JSRD. When the genetic mutation is inherited, there is a risk of multiple children in the same family being affected(19)
Early identification and intervention generally allows for the best functional outcomes and prevention of complications related to renal or hepatic abnormalities(1)
